Hey {first_name, "there"},

I have to be honest with you: this is a terrible newsletter. And the reasons why are useful I think. If you can endure a newsletter full of self-flagellation (which sounds like the sort of specialist journal that might make you a bit of cash on Substack…), we can explore together what makes a good newsletter by counter-example.

My work on newsletters with publishers makes it clear to me:

  1. What's wrong with the newsletter version of OM&HB
  2. How I could fix it

But finding the time to do that would be a challenge…
(Should I? What would you like to see out of this newsletter?)
Thank you for putting up with my crap newsletter. I hope you find it valuable despite its manifold failings!

sections: What makes a great newsletter? We're still figuring that out, but there's enough good research and evidence out there about engaging people via email to make it clear I'm doing something very wrong. People
respond to mine like those over-excited folks in the lead image…
Like many people who work in education and training, sometimes my courses amount to “do what I say, not what I do”. I was reminded of that during the first week of
, while I was describing the key characteristics of a successful newsletter. It dawned on me that
every single characteristic I described of is entirely absent from the newsletter you get when you hit the “subscribe” button here.
Lack of regularity means lack of habit formation

When is an email newsletter going to arrive? If it just turns up when it turns up, I have to really love it to leap straight to it in my crowded in-box. On the other hand, if I can rely on it being in my in-box at a particular time, I can build it into my routine. If I do that often enought, it becomes a habit — and thus I become a loyal reader.
every morning over coffee because I can rely on it being there. I usually read through
early in the afternoon because that’s when it turns up. It's a great way of easing myself back into work after lunch.
So, by failing to publish regularly,
misses the chance of becoming a habit in your reading. It's not a vital plank of your information day. Fail.
No structure, no sense of familiarity
An email that has a reliable structure — look at the excellent

for example — becomes a familiar, comforting read. You know what to expect, and you know what your favourite bit of the email is, be it, for example, the cartoon halfway down, or the competition near the end. This is, simply, magazine thinking applied to newsletters. Readers can get familiar with newsletters in the same way they get familiar with magazines.

Additionally, the structure serves to make it easier for me to create (or would, if I had one). Find three stories to link to, give context, and then publish? Easy! Should I do a piece of analysis, or a links round-up, or a piece of advice? Hard!
By failing to adhere to any regular structure,
is both harder for me to create, and difficult for you, the reader, to get comfortable with. Fail.
